subject: Re: [junit] Standalone or "requires environment" information
msgSnippet: ... Your SQL is code and it also need to be unit tested. This cannot be done with mock objects. It needs to be executed by something which understands SQL. If
messageBody:
> I prefer the idea of well designed code that makes it easy to substitute
> the /environment/ for a MockObject <www.mockobjects.com> instead. This,
> IMHO, is the true nature of *unit* tests. What you want to know is that
> your code responds to the environment in the expected way.
>
Your SQL is code and it also need to be unit tested. This cannot be done
with mock
objects. It needs to be executed by something which understands SQL. If
necessary
you can try to make this layer as thin as possible and abstract enough to
substitute with
mock objects at the next level up.

> Thus you create mock objets for a faulty database: method call throws
> exception; a normal db call: the method returns a valid response; etc.
>
That is an advantage of mock objects. I would use a mixture of mock and real
in the same test class.

Mock objects have there place. I have used them recently to test servlets
without
a container and to test that Swing models fire events. I don't think all
JDBC tests
should be done with mock objects however.

> This gives you complete control over the responses you expect from the
> environment, and allow you to test your code under expected conditions.
> It also means that your unit test suite will be a lot faster.
>
But maybe the tests are fast enough even when they exercise the whole
system from end to end. I did my ejb testing in container using a real
database and my tests weren't too slow.

I had similar thoughts to David. My motivation was working from home when I
didn't have access to the database but would still like to execute as many
tests as possible.
Other classes of test might be long running stress tests.

-- Neil Swingler
